[Bears]: 24418, recommendation for Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund Board of Trustees.

[Bears]: June 10th, 2024 by electronic delivery regarding recommendation for the Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund Board of Trustees.

[Bears]: I respect the request and recommend the honorable body approve the following candidates to serve on the Board of Trustees for the Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund.

[Bears]: Yes, we just moved through the item and it has been disposed of.

[Bears]: I'm happy to take it up under public participation or public participation item from Charles Rodriguez.

[Bears]: I'm gonna keep reading.

[Bears]: In accordance with the MedFed Affordable Housing Trust Fund Ordinance, the Board of Trustees shall be appointed by the Mayor.

[Bears]: Upon approval from the City Council, the Board must consist of seven members, including the Mayor or their designee.

[Bears]: The Ordinance stipulates that the initial appointment of Trustees must be staggered, with three members serving a one-year term and the remaining four serving a two-year term.

[Bears]: Subsequent appointments and reappointments except for the Mayor's seat will be for two-year periods.

[Bears]: Below are the six recommended candidates with their initial staggered terms.

[Bears]: One, Kayla Lesson, two-year term.

[Bears]: Two, Roberta Cameron, two-year term.

[Bears]: Three, Lisa Ann Davidson, two-year term.

[Bears]: Four, Carrie Weaver, one-year term.

[Bears]: Five, Penelope Taylor, one-year term.

[Bears]: Six, Lisa Son, one-year term.

[Bears]: Furthermore, information on each candidate is enclosed to support the candidate recommendation submission.

[Bears]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: I would invite the Office of Planning, Development, and Sustainability Director or the Chief of Staff to present the nominees.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Welcome, Aditi.

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: Sure.

[Bears]: I mean, I would have.

[Bears]: Please don't disrupt the public meeting we have business to attend to.

[Bears]: If a councilor wished to make a... On a motion for councilor to recess for five minutes, seconded by Councilor San Buenaventura, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Thank you on the recess.

[Bears]: The motion was disposed of per the council rules.

[Bears]: There was a vote that was taken and disposed of it.

[Bears]: The agenda, I can't call people out of order, that needs to be a vote of the council.

[Bears]: Councilor Scott probably could have proposed that, there could have been a second, we could have had a vote on it.

[Bears]: I can't just discretionarily move items around, that is not my role.

[Bears]: The agenda's written the way it's written, public participation's at the end of the meeting.

[Bears]: There was a vote, there was a motion and a vote.

[Bears]: Once an item is disposed of with a motion and a vote, it is concluded.

[Bears]: It's just the rules, thank you.

[Bears]: I'm sorry, I have to follow the rules.

[Bears]: I have to follow the rules.

[Bears]: I have to follow the rules.

[Bears]: All right, let's keep yelling personal attacks.

[Bears]: I don't think that'll get us anywhere.

[Bears]: If this is how it's gonna go,

[Bears]: I'm just following the rules.

[Bears]: You should, you don't have to do a vote, but yeah, 842, yeah.

[Bears]: The Office of Plenary Development and Sustainability has received and reviewed applications for the Board of Trustees and has met applicants to understand their backgrounds and interests in affordable housing.

[Bears]: The Affordable Housing Trust Fund will convene once a month on Wednesday with its first meeting to be scheduled in July 2024.

[Bears]: The specific date for monthly meetings will be determined after consultation with the trustees.

[Bears]: The trust may establish a subcommittee or a working group that will meet more frequently to develop an action plan for the trust.

[Bears]: Below are the six recommended candidates with their initial staggered terms.

[Bears]: Kayla Lesson, two year term.

[Bears]: Kayla Lesson is a resident of South Medford and works as an asset manager with legal background.

[Bears]: Kayla has 13 years of experience working for a real estate company that owns mixed income apartment buildings in the greater Boston area.

[Bears]: Kayla has worked with Mass Housing, HUD,

[Bears]: and HUD regulators to manage regulatory compliance.

[Bears]: She is well-versed in affordable housing policies and programs initiated by Mass Housing, the Executive Offices of Housing and Livable Communities, and Mass Development.

[Bears]: Roberta Cameron is the Community Preservation Act Manager with the City of Somerville and serves as Chairperson on the Medford Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: As a former planning consultant, Roberta has 25 years experience working with Massachusetts cities and towns.

[Bears]: Her areas of expertise include affordable housing,

[Bears]: economic development, land use, public facilities, and impact assessment.

[Bears]: She's also established and advised affordable housing trusts and community preservation committees across the region.

[Bears]: Lisa Ann Davidson is a resident and deputy housing director with the city of Somerville.

[Bears]: In the past, Lisa has served as a trustee on the Somerville Affordable Housing Trust Fund and as a director of the Somerville Homeless Coalition.

[Bears]: She's created five permanent support housing programs and has worked with the unhoused population for nearly 20 years.

[Bears]: Carrie Weaver resides in Glenwood and works as a child care professional.

[Bears]: She is passionate about affordable housing and currently lives in an affordable home.

[Bears]: Carrie is eager to share her lived experience in affordable homes.

[Bears]: She has also assisted the Medford Housing Authority in administering the family self-sufficiency program for voucher holders.

[Bears]: Lisa's son works as an architectural designer specializing in sustainability and affordable housing.

[Bears]: She holds a dual master's degree in architecture and urban planning with a focus on ecological design.

[Bears]: Lisa has worked with local housing authorities to retrofit affordable housing in order to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

[Bears]: She also has experience reviewing development projects and has volunteered at Homeless Outreach and Habitat for Humanity.

[Bears]: Penelope Taylor works at the City of Somerville's Office of Housing Stability as a Program Development Policy and Outreach Coordinator.

[Bears]: She advocates for low-income clients with housing needs and assesses the effectiveness of housing programs.

[Bears]: She serves on the Somerville Residential Anti-Displacement Task Force, researching housing policy suggestions for the city, and also served on the Union Square Neighborhood Council Board for three terms, focusing on affordable housing, and all six of the appointees are Medford residents.

[Bears]: With that, I'll go to Aditi.

[Bears]: If there's anything else you'd like to present, and then we can go to members of the council for any questions before we vote on the appointments.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: 24-421, Ordinance Creating a South Street Historic District.

[Bears]: I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body adopt the enclosed ordinance proposed by the Medford Historic District Commission in accordance with the Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 40C, Section 3, Creating a South Street Historic District.

[Bears]: A map of the South Street Historic District dated November 9, 2023 is also enclosed.

[Bears]: In accordance with the requirements of establishing a historic district,

[Bears]: One, an investigation and report was made by the Medford Historic District Commission with the support of a consultant, Skelly Preservation Services, and transmitted to the Community Development Board and the Massachusetts Historical Commission for their respective consideration and recommendations.

[Bears]: Both entities have considered and recommend

[Bears]: approval of the proposed South Street Historic District, encloses a copy of the Community Development Board recommendation to approve the creation of the South Street Local Historic District, and the Massachusetts Historical Commission discussed the proposed district at their September 13, 2023 meeting, for which they ultimately concluded and incorporated into their minutes that the quote, Massachusetts Historical Commission encourages the City of Medford to establish the South Street Local Historic District.

[Bears]: The Medford Historic District Commission held a public hearing on February 8th, 2024, and notices were mailed in accordance to the statute to ordiners as they appear on the real estate tax list.

[Bears]: And a final report dated February 20th, 2024, with recommendations by the Medford Historic District Commission is also enclosed.

[Bears]: The above ordinance has been reviewed by Attorney Robin Stein at KP Law PC, and the recommended changes have been incorporated.

[Bears]: Further, the sufficiency of the vote required by the council would be a two-thirds majority.

[Bears]: Medford Historic District Commission Chairperson Christopher Bader will be in attendance to present this proposed ordinance to the council and answer any questions from the council.

[Bears]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Brandon Lingo, current mayor.

[Bears]: Chris, thank you for being here.

[Bears]: I welcome you to the podium.

[Bears]: I think I saw some other members of the commission here for a while.

[Bears]: Has anyone stuck it out?

[Bears]: Thank you both for sticking it out.

[Bears]: You're welcome to join at the podium if you'd like, and we're happy to hear the presentation.

[Bears]: If you'd like, I'm also happy to read the proposed changes to the ordinance at some point.

[Bears]: You just let me know.

[Bears]: Give me one moment.

[Bears]: Actually, give me two moments.

[Bears]: Then I think you need to click play from start.

[Bears]: If you scroll up a little bit.

[Bears]: You might have to scroll back.

[Bears]: 24427, appropriation for Medford High School MSBA feasibility study.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the City Council, I respect the request and recommend that your Honorable Body vote as reviewed, the following as reviewed by the Massachusetts School Business Authority, I think I should say School Building Authority, and we may need to correct that.

[Bears]: that the City of Medford appropriates the amount of $3 million, $3 million, for the purpose of paying costs for the feasibility study for Medford High School, currently located at 489 Winthrop Street, Medford, Massachusetts, including the payment of all costs, incidental or related thereto, and for which the City of Medford may be eligible for a grant from the Massachusetts School Building Authority, MSBA, and the set amount to be expended under the direction of the Medford Comprehensive High School Building Committee.

[Bears]: To meet this appropriation, the Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, proposes the use of $3 million in free cash.

[Bears]: The City of Medford acknowledges that the MSBA's grant program is a non-entitlement discretionary program based on need, as determined by the MSBA, and any costs the City of Medford incurs in excess of the grant approved by and received from the MSBA shall be the sole responsibility of the City of Medford, and that the amount authorized pursuant to this vote shall be reduced by any grant amount set forth in the feasibility study agreement that may be executed between the City of Medford and the MSBA.

[Bears]: I'll read chapter 43, section 22.

[Bears]: Any ordinance order or resolution may be passed through all its stages of legislation at one session, provided that no member of the council objects thereto.

[Bears]: But if any member of the council objects, the measure shall be postponed for that meeting.

[Bears]: Ordinances have multiple stages of legislation, a first reading, a second reading, and a third reading, whereas none of the paper, at least the paper before us, and if your intent is to apply it to 24428, 24432,

[Bears]: And just before we continue, I just want to explain the free cash process.

[Bears]: As Councilor Lazzaro was noting, the previous free cash certification was for July 1 of 2022.

[Bears]: That was in the amount of $25 million and change.

[Bears]: Last week, the Department of the Division of Local Services, I believe,

[Bears]: issued a free cash certification for the city as of July 1, 2023.

[Bears]: While the free cash amount was not certified, and that amount was $34 million, while that amount had not been certified when the financial task force was having its discussions, we were very aware

[Bears]: that the reason for free cash balance amounts and the certification of amounts was due to essentially three factors.

[Bears]: One was the use of ARPA funds provided by the federal government instead of free cash in many situations over the past three fiscal years.

[Bears]: The second was the conservative estimation of local receipts as part of revenues.

[Bears]: I see Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Was the conservative estimation of local receipts.

[Bears]: As part of the local revenues, as we heard from our finance director this year, the amount estimated for local receipts for the fiscal 25 budget is at the upper bounds of comfort of what we have submitted, and I'm seeing a smirk and smile.

[Bears]: Mr. Dickinson, and it's a fingers crossed.

[Bears]: And the third was turned back to open positions, most of which have been filled, there was no expectation whatsoever by anyone familiar with the finances of the city that we will continue to see free cash balance increases of five to $10 million a year.

[Bears]: Those are not reliable revenue sources, they're not stable revenue sources, and they are not responsible revenue sources to base our budgets on or to suggest that we have enough funding for Medford Public Schools or for DPW or for a new Medford Fire Headquarters.

[Bears]: So those are the facts of free cash.

[Bears]: Those are the financial statistics of our community.

[Bears]: That is why even though there is a free cash balance certified

[Bears]: as of July 1, 2023 for fiscal 24, $34 million that we need the stable recurring revenues as proposed by the mayor and approved by the council for the override votes in November.

[Bears]: This is not, free cash is not a solution to those problems.

[Bears]: It never has been and it never will be.

[Bears]: We also have this amount, which is good, basically thanks to the federal ARPA program.

[Bears]: There is a documentation in here outlining the draft free cash plan of the administration, which we can discuss tonight and consider further as a council.

[Bears]: It brings us back down very, very quickly with our capital needs to the 10 to $15 million range of free cash reserves recommended by all of the state financial agencies for

[Bears]: communities to have I think it's between five and 7% of their annual budget in a reserve and that's where this will bring us so.

[Bears]: The federal ARPA program did give us some spending in recent years that we otherwise wouldn't have had.

[Bears]: It gave us a little boost to address capital needs.

[Bears]: Those capital needs, even if we spent all 34 million on them tomorrow, would not address the massive capital deficit we have for our city facilities, school facilities, roads, sidewalks, water and sewer system, which as we've discussed at numerous meetings of this council, is in the hundreds of millions, if not billions of dollars.

[Bears]: Seeing none in the chamber and no hands on Zoom, on the motion of Vice President Collins, as seconded by Councilor Leming, Madam Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: As amended.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: from Mayor Bernalino Kern to fund General Stabilization Establish and Fund Capital Stabilization Funds.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honorable Body vote to appropriate free cash in the amount of $6 million into the General Stabilization Fund established earlier this year by Your Honorable Body.

[Bears]: As you know, the vast majority of cities and towns in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts have a General Stabilization Fund.

[Bears]: In order to provide for emergencies and unforeseen expenses,

[Bears]: a simple majority of the City Council is required to appropriate funds into a stabilization fund.

[Bears]: Further, in accordance with Chapter 40, Section 5b of the General Laws, I respect the request and recommend that Your Honorable Body take the following actions, each requiring a two-thirds majority vote of the City Council for establishment.

[Bears]: One, establish a capital stabilization fund and vote to approve $5 million of free cash to this fund.

[Bears]: Two, establish a water and sewer capital stabilization fund

[Bears]: and vote to appropriate $2 million of retained earnings to this fund.

[Bears]: As you are aware, free cash and retained earnings are only available after certification through June 30th of each year.

[Bears]: Each year without a stabilization fund, the city could face significant challenges in addressing emergencies or capital needs from July 1st until free cash is certified.

[Bears]: Chapter 40, section 5B of the general law stipulates that, quote, cities, towns, and districts may create one or more stabilization funds and appropriate any amount to the funds.

[Bears]: The Division of Local Services, Financial Management Resource Bureau,

[Bears]: Notes in a published article, quote, a city or town's capital assets are a vital part of providing essential services to residents.

[Bears]: Capital assets include public buildings and structures, roadways, parks and fields, large equipment like dump trucks, mowers, fire engines, fire breathing apparatus, police cruisers, radio equipment, as well as land acquisitions.

[Bears]: Major repairs to a capital asset or when it needs to be replaced unexpectedly or reaches its expected useful life early can be a significant shock to the budget.

[Bears]: Additionally, deferred maintenance of capital needs,

[Bears]: Existing capital assets is a major contributor to capital failures, as these necessary upkeep costs are sometimes avoided in the interest of balancing the budget.

[Bears]: One way to better prepare for capital expenditures, both planned and unexpected, is to establish a special purpose capital stabilization fund dedicated to funding regular required capital repairs and maintenance.

[Bears]: In close, please find a draft free cash plan for your review and input.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: And in terms of the free cash plan, we have a free cash and retained earnings update.

[Bears]: Based on the unaudited balance sheet submitted, this is from the Department of Revenue Division of Local Services, notification of free cash approval.

[Bears]: I hereby certify that the amount of available funds for free cash as of July 1 for City of Medford is General Fund $34,241,981, Enterprise Fund Water and Sewer $11,164,741,

[Bears]: This certification is in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 59, Section 23 as amended.

[Bears]: As per requests to the Council dated June 18, 2024, I am requesting the following funds be appropriated from free cash, $6 million General Stabilization Fund, $5 million Capital Stabilization Fund, $3 million Mass School Building Authority Feasibility Study,

[Bears]: for a total of $14 million.

[Bears]: The capital stabilization funding mentioned would be a source for fiscal 2024 and prior year capital improvement needs.

[Bears]: For the remaining funds, I anticipate the following future appropriation requests.

[Bears]: I welcome the Council's input on future appropriation requests before my office and the finance team work to finalize an initial roadmap for the funds.

[Bears]: $1 million additional funding to renovate the Hegner Center.

[Bears]: 2.5 million fire department fleet replacements, 2 million pension liability, 2 million fiscal year 2025 capital improvements, 2 million fiscal year 2026 capital improvements, $9.5 million.

[Bears]: Please note that we do not anticipate future certifications to be as large as the last few years.

[Bears]: There are many factors that contribute to the balance in free cash today, including conservative estimating of revenues in pandemic years, vacancies in personnel positions, health insurance budget turnbacks, and the availability of ARPA funds.

[Bears]: While best practices still dictate that we should be somewhat conservative on revenue estimates, we push the envelope for fiscal 25 with our finance directors out.

[Bears]: We're now able to process personal hires faster than we were able to in the past, and we are not expecting any health insurance turnbacks.

[Bears]: Instead, actuals are showing a deficit for fiscal 24, and the ability to appropriate ARPA funds ends December 31, 2024.

[Bears]: Finally, as the council may know, the Division of Local Services General Stabilization recommended goal is five to 7% of the current operating budget range.

[Bears]: For Medford, five to 7% of the fiscal 25 budget would be 9.47, between 9.47 and 13.26 million.

[Bears]: on funds certified for water sewer enterprise.

[Bears]: As the council knows, $2 million is proposed for a capital stabilization fund specifically for water and sewer, and the city is presently performing a water system analysis capital plan and rate study, which will help further inform the city in its planning efforts to address the aging water infrastructure across the city.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Reinaldo Kernmayer.

[Bears]: So right there, we're talking about $25 million.

[Bears]: sorry, $23.5 million of that $34 million going either to stabilization funds or specific projects.

[Bears]: There was a request for us to review an input on the free cash plan, so at some point we should discuss how we want to do that.

[Bears]: And with that, I will go to Vice President Collins and then Chief of Staff Nazarian.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: On the, I'm just gonna put it out there.

[Bears]: I'm gonna go to the Chief of Staff.

[Bears]: We have a B paper to schedule a committee of the whole with the administration to discuss the draft free cash plan.

[Bears]: And then Councilor Collins has also made a motion to approve the main paper.

[Bears]: A second by Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: And we only have

[Bears]: Three more papers to go.

[Bears]: This is the water and sewer capital stabilization and the appropriation of $2 million in retained earnings.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Yes, six in the affirmative, one in the negative, one absent, the motion passes.

[Bears]: And we have established these savings accounts, appropriated funds to them.

[Bears]: Those funds have not been spent.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: All right, we'll move to 24432, acceptance of shared service statute.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the city council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body vote to accept the provisions of Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 71, Section 37M, which would allow the city to share services between municipal departments and the school department.

[Bears]: As you'll see in the enclosed statute, the acceptance of the statute requires majority approval of the city council and the school committee.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Motions, orders, and resolutions 24441 offered by Councilor Scarpelli, whereas the Mayor and Medford City Council have repeatedly stated their goal to ensure the highest degree of transparency and accountability in all governmental matters, and whereas on June 28, 2024, Medford City Councilor George Scarpelli sent a letter

[Bears]: to the Office of the Attorney General and the Office of the State Auditor.

[Bears]: And whereas the letter of Councilor Scott Polley raised various issues relating to the vote taken on significant municipal financial matters and the actions of the Medford City Council.

[Bears]: And whereas, in light of the long-term absence of an appointed city solicitor in the city of Medford and the fact that the city's private legal counsel is a law firm hired by the mayor, and whereas the director of operations of the office of the state auditor responded to Councilor Scarpelli's letter, that the state auditor would, quote, examine the issues raised in the letter if the examination of these issues had the approval of a majority vote of the city council and the mayor, as required by state statute, and whereas the fairest and most objective fashion to resolve the issues raised in Councilor Scarpelli's letter is to have an outside agency address these issues,

[Bears]: and determine the most appropriate way to address these issues.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, we are resolved that the Medford City Council approve and authorize the Office of the State Auditor to examine the issues set forth in said letter.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I move that Councilor Scarpelli to approve the resolution, seconded by.

[Bears]: Second, I'll second it.

[Bears]: You can.

[Bears]: Second.

[Bears]: Oh, we have a second.

[Bears]: Well, and the financial team communicated to this council at budget meetings and committee of the whole, that there was going to be a free cash balance this year.

[Bears]: similar to the previous few years for three major reasons.

[Bears]: The use of federal funds, ARPA funding from the federal government, one-time funds, in the place where free cash reserves may have otherwise been used.

[Bears]: That was a certification, yes.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: It was a one-time surplus and is not reliably budgetable.

[Bears]: We don't know how much is coming until it's certified.

[Bears]: And the financial experts on our finance team have said that we should not expect to have free cash balances of $9 million going forward.

[Bears]: It would be much more that what they have said in multiple meetings that we've had in this chamber is that we should expect, similar to what was under Mayor McGlynn and Mayor Burke, between $500,000 and $2 million free cash balance surpluses certified at the end of the year.

[Bears]: On a petition for a special permit for hours filed by Panda Express, 491 Riverside Avenue, Medford MA 02155.

[Bears]: The petitioner is seeking to extend the hours of operation of the restaurant in a commercial C1 zoning district at 4091 Riverside Avenue, parcel ID Q1511.

[Bears]: The petition seeks a special permit for hours, Monday through Sunday, and actually, there's an amendment, so I'm going to read the revised request now.

[Bears]: Panda Express, revised request, we request an extended hour special permit to operate until 12 a.m., Monday through Thursday, and 1 a.m.

[Bears]: on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

[Bears]: This is in line with extended hour special permits recently granted to Great American Beer Hall, Snappy Patty's, and Pinky's Pizza.

[Bears]: We believe the disruption to the neighborhood from these extended hours will be minimal, because we are mostly surrounded by businesses and do not have a drive-through,

[Bears]: but a set of ample parking for visitors and food delivery drivers to park and come inside.

[Bears]: We look forward to working with the council to develop a plan that works for the neighborhood.

[Bears]: The petition and plan may be viewed in the office of the City Clerk, Room 103, Medford City Hall, Medford MA, call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations aids.

[Bears]: City of Medford is an EEOA 504 employer by order of the City Council, signed Adam L. Herdeby, City Clerk.

[Bears]: 24-467 offered by mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Capital Stabilization Fund appropriation requests.

[Bears]: September 12 2024 regarding Capital Stabilization Fund appropriation request dear President Bears and members of the city council I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the following two appropriations from the Capital Stabilization Fund Spring Street at Central Avenue traffic signal safety improvement project

[Bears]: any amount of $283,535 and matching funds for the MAS, Department of Environmental Protection, VW and refuse truck electric grant program to purchase one electric refuse truck in the amount of $178,000.

[Bears]: As your honorable body knows, the capital stabilization fund presently has a balance of $5 million.

[Bears]: Further, any appropriation from stabilization account requires a two thirds majority vote of the city council.

[Bears]: Director of Traffic and Transportation, Todd Blake, will be present to answer any questions on the Traffic Safety Improvement Project, and CPA Manager, Teresa DuPont, will be available to present any and

[Bears]: We'll be present to answer any questions on the electric refuse truck project.

[Bears]: Finally, I respectfully request that both, or at least the traffic signal safety project, that your Honorable Body move forward tonight as the city is under some tight timelines for award, and Director Blake will elaborate on those at or before the meeting.

[Bears]: And we did receive, I'm sorry, thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[Bears]: We did receive a communication from Director Blake.

[Bears]: He's also here, but I'll read the communication.

[Bears]: I'm providing the following additional information in anticipation of some possible questions regarding this request.

[Bears]: The city's director of traffic and transportation, as well as the city engineer and former city engineer, current DPW commissioner,

[Bears]: Prioritize this project, that is the Central Ave Spring Street traffic signal.

[Bears]: Prioritize this project when developing and prioritizing the city's capital project list slash needs.

[Bears]: The existing traffic signal is substandard, not meeting national and state guidelines for traffic signals.

[Bears]: Specifically, it lacks the minimum number of signal heads per approach to only having one per approach.

[Bears]: The traffic signal also lacks pedestrian actuation and indications, walk slash don't walk indications, et cetera.

[Bears]: This project is necessary to add these important safety features as well as to provide accessible ramps

[Bears]: so the accommodations are available to all persons of all abilities.

[Bears]: The city hired a consultant to design the project, which includes an overhead mast arm for better visibility and to achieve the two signals per approach standard.

[Bears]: The city secured allocated funding using CityARPA to design and construct the project.

[Bears]: The amount sought through that program accounted for paying the consultant as well as paying for the construction of the project based on the construction cost estimate produced by that design.

[Bears]: During the bidding process, the city received three qualified bids.

[Bears]: However, unfortunately, all three bids are higher than the estimated construction costs, substantially higher.

[Bears]: Therefore, the project requires additional funding to be able to award a contract and proceed with construction.

[Bears]: The city project is seeking $283,535 from the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: For context, the total construction cost is $749,535 based on the low bid plus estimated police details.

[Bears]: The construction estimate had been $466,135.

[Bears]: The design fees are $141,900.

[Bears]: We do not anticipate receiving lower bids if rebidding the project, and there do not appear to be cost savings from value engineering.

[Bears]: It is already minimum work required.

[Bears]: There are multiple time constraints involved.

[Bears]: Since it is ARPA funded, the funds need to be allocated by the end of the calendar year.

[Bears]: Also, the contract must be awarded within 45 days of the bid opening.

[Bears]: Because of these time constraints, we also not only ask for the funds, but we request approval be given tonight.

[Bears]: without continuing to subsequent meetings, this will help ensure the award within the proper time constraint.

[Bears]: If we do not move forward or miss our window of opportunity to construct this project, safety will remain compromised at this location, possibly leading to incidents and or claims that could be avoided.

[Bears]: Thank you for your time and consideration on this important matter.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Todd Blake, Director of Traffic and Transportation.

[Bears]: So that's the letter.

[Bears]: Any comments, questions, thoughts by members of the council or questions for Director Blake or Manager DuPont?

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: That was an error.

[Bears]: So that's an error in the letter for the mayor.

[Bears]: It's an appropriation request.

[Bears]: So, yeah.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Kaya and Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: And I want to note that the mayor has reached out to schedule a committee of the whole in October to discuss stabilization fund requests.

[Bears]: Now that ARPA funding is expiring, we're coming back to why free cash exists and exists for these one-time expenditures.

[Bears]: So the mayor, I'm working with the mayor to schedule a committee of the whole on an October Wednesday to discuss

[Bears]: for the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: And then we have the needs for departments from the stabilization funds, I think, mainly starting with the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: These two items were urgent, and that's why they're before us tonight, and the mayor communicated that to me, in addition to this letter as well, in the note that most of the other stuff will be coming to us through a committee process for review

[Bears]: And I just think Spring Street and Central Ave, that's a rough intersection if anyone's ever been walking through it or driving through it or biking through it.

[Bears]: And hopefully between this project and the speed humps, we'll see some safety improvements there.

[Bears]: Gaston, name and address for the record.

[Bears]: You have three minutes.

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Director DuPont on this in a second.

[Bears]: It sounded like she said, Manager DuPont, I keep promoting you.

[Bears]: But it sounded like you said sourcing would take 60 to 90 days.

[Bears]: That includes a procurement process, if I'm correct.

[Bears]: Part of the chapter, I can't remember the chapter, but the procurement law is 30B.

[Bears]: The chapter procurement laws is that you have to have a defined source of the funds before you can go out to procurement.

[Bears]: So I think that's what the issue is here that they have to have the funds approved, then go to procurement to get the vehicle.

[Bears]: And they're just you're matching the grant amount that was authorized by DEP.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I think that's the answer there.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: The bidding is after the funding is authorized, and if the bid comes in lower than the authorized funding, then I believe that money would revert back to the source of funding.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the public or members of the council?

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: On the motion of Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Leming to approve, Ms.

[Bears]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: We'll go to public participation.

[Bears]: Public participation is open.

[Bears]: If you can raise your hand on Zoom or go to the podium, I do have two letters to read, but I will read those after public participation by people who are either in the room or on Zoom.

[Bears]: Any public participation by anyone in the chamber or on Zoom?

[Bears]: Please raise your hand on Zoom or speak up in the chamber.

[Bears]: Seeing none, I have two letters to read.

[Bears]: These were sent to me by constituents, sent to the president and requested to be read at the council meeting.

[Bears]: These are not reflective of, these are not statements by me.

[Bears]: I am reading letters from the public for public participation.

[Bears]: Dear councilors, I have witnessed the appalling personal attacks against our progressive city councils by people incorrectly calling themselves All Medford.

[Bears]: They have screamed, interrupted, kept people from speaking, and ignored honest answers to their concerns.

[Bears]: Meetings have dragged on to 1 a.m.

[Bears]: Our new city councilors are sincere, thoughtful people trying to make Medford a better place for all, with more affordable housing, an end to discrimination, and enough funding to support our underfunded public schools.

[Bears]: One needn't agree with them on everything, but disrespectful conduct keeps our city from moving forward.

[Bears]: I have lived in Medford for 43 years,

[Bears]: and sadly will be departing soon for senior housing.

[Bears]: I can honestly attest that Medford is a better place now, with better schools, more diversity, a brand new police station, interesting new restaurants, and potentially a new fire station than it was when I first came here.

[Bears]: The effort to overturn the regressive Proposition 2.5, which has resulted in underfunding our schools and roads, is a positive thing.

[Bears]: Of course, in the end, it will be put to the voters.

[Bears]: I do understand that this may pose a small hardship for low-income homeowners, but most cities and towns have already passed overrides.

[Bears]: People can, of course, vote against it, but they should not attack those who, in good faith, want to improve our city with essential funding by putting it on the ballot or misrepresent their views, as was done in heated discussions of the real estate transfer fee.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Susan Gerard, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: That's the first letter, and then I have another letter.

[Bears]: Dear Medford City Council President Zach Bares, I request you read this letter at the next City Council meeting.

[Bears]: This past year, I've attended many City Council meetings, mostly on Zoom, a few in City Hall chambers, largely because of closed captioning, which allows me to hear more of what people in the chambers are saying.

[Bears]: The deficient sound system in City Hall, I understand, is going to be renovated, and that will be good for everyone.

[Bears]: A second reason I have often preferred not to be physically present in the City Council Chambers is because of an unruly mob of residents who come to meetings to register their displeasure on hot-button issues like the budget, real estate transfer fee, or renaming of the Columbus School.

[Bears]: These meetings have been perforated by the group ironically now known as All Medford, the small group of residents regularly indulging, screaming, shouting, and insulting our Revolution Medford-endorsed City Councilors,

[Bears]: After one particularly contentious meeting I attended in City Hall, councillors were individually singled out for repeated personal attacks and subjected to blanket attacks on all of them because they belonged to our revolution, Medford.

[Bears]: I was so disturbed by the vitriol, the lies, the hatred, and the unwillingness to even listen to what Councilors had to say.

[Bears]: I'm so sorry that you, Zach, and the other OR-endorsed Councilors have been subjected to this abuse.

[Bears]: I want to assure you that a majority of residents who voted for you and all our Revolution Medford candidates still support the work you've been doing or attempting to do in Medford.

[Bears]: Know that we are still here.

[Bears]: All Medford is not all Medford.

[Bears]: You were elected on the basis of the People's Platform, and we who voted for you still want to work on that agenda.

[Bears]: the city budget we need to support the schools and city services, the creation of an equitable and welcoming city government, desperately needed affordable housing, community safety, and a climate-resilient community.

[Bears]: As we explore solutions to these and other issues, I support you, as do the many who voted for our Revolution Medford candidates.

[Bears]: Please do not allow the not-all Medford to derail or curtail any of your intentions, goals, or efforts.

[Bears]: We who support you are many.

[Bears]: There are a small group of disgruntled people whose leadership and control has been rejected by the voters.

[Bears]: voters.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Eileen Lerner, Knight-Adams Circle, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: Those are the letters.

[Bears]: Is there anyone else who has any public comment at this time?

[Bears]: Seeing none, is there anything else that anyone wants to look at on the agenda?

[Bears]: We're at unfinished business, seeing no motions.

[Bears]: Is there a motion on the floor?

[Bears]: On the motion to adjourn by Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: It looks like he's dropped off.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: The motion passes and the meeting is adjourned.

[Bears]: I need everyone to stick around.

[Bears]: Hi there, sorry about that.

[Bears]: I am currently sitting at the intersection of Main Street and South Street.

[Bears]: So subject matter expert at the moment.

[Bears]: I just wanted to note a thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you to the Bike Commission and to Emily O'Brien for your work on this.

[Bears]: And thank you to Todd for being our liaison with MassDOT.

[Bears]: But I also just wanted to note

[Bears]: I think it's essential that we get this right.

[Bears]: Medford wasn't built for the level of car volume that we have now.

[Bears]: And just because we pasted an overpass of Route 16 and the highway through it doesn't mean that the rest of our streets can actually handle

[Bears]: the car volume that we have today.

[Bears]: And that's why it's essential that we move in the direction that we're moving to make Medford more accessible for all, not just people with cars.

[Bears]: I'm one who uses my car all the time, but I would use other modes of transportation if I felt like I could get where I was going in a reasonable amount of time.

[Bears]: The Craddock Bridge is the only crossing of the Mystic River for about a mile or more on either side of the east or west.

[Bears]: And we know that it was deeply impacted by the massive volumes of car traffic that have been throughput through that bridge and through the intersections that we're talking about.

[Bears]: by Interstate 93 and by the overbuilt Route 16 overpass.

[Bears]: And I think it's essential that we get this signalization and rebuild of Main and Mystic right, because what we're talking about in Medford Square and what we're talking about on Mystic Ave is returning to a people-centered era, not a car-centered era.

[Bears]: All of the spots on Mystic Ave just south of the bridge and just south of the 16 overpass used to be a vibrant walkable neighborhood.

[Bears]: Medford Square used to be a vibrant walkable neighborhood.

[Bears]: The car supremacy and the building of the highway destroyed so much of the community that was built there.

[Bears]: And now that we're trying to restore it, this isn't the essential link.

[Bears]: to making it work.

[Bears]: So I appreciate the bike commission's work.

[Bears]: I appreciate everyone's conversation here in this meeting.

[Bears]: I also think putting that layer of what do we want our community to look like and how do we want to make sure that it's safe for everyone to

[Bears]: have community and link together in our squares is an important part of the conversation, too.

[Bears]: I don't think the 25% design hit that mark, but I'm hopeful that upcoming designs will.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: 24473 presented by Mayor Brianna Locurn, Capital Stabilization Fund appropriation request.

[Bears]: And we have a revised letter from today.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the city council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the following appropriations from the Capital Stabilization Fund.

[Bears]: Replacement of the water heater at Brooks Elementary School, $267,000.

[Bears]: Roadway patching in the amount of $112,728.

[Bears]: replacement of light poles in city parking lots in the amount of $105,000.

[Bears]: City Hall elevator repair unforeseen costs and upgrades of electrical and fire alarm systems needed for code compliance, 75,000.

[Bears]: Repairs at Brooks Estate, use of funds must comply with city procurement policies and procedures and state procurement law in the amount of 55,000.

[Bears]: As your honorable body knows, the capital stabilization fund currently has a balance of $4,538,465 given the appropriations made

[Bears]: on September 17th, 2024.

[Bears]: If all of the above are approved, the capital stabilization fund would have $3,923,737 that remains.

[Bears]: Any appropriation from the stabilization account requires a two-thirds majority vote of the City Council.

[Bears]: At the City Council's Committee of the Whole meeting on Wednesday, October 2nd, Assistant Superintendent Peter Cushing will be available for questions on the water heater replacement.

[Bears]: City Engineer Owen Wartella will be here for the roadway and patching project.

[Bears]: Superintendent of Ours, Steven Randazzo on the light poles and Facilities Director Paul Riggi on the elevator project.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I reviewed the records of the August 15th meeting and I found them in order and I would move approval.

[Bears]: Sure.

[Bears]: Thanks, Madam President.

[Bears]: Yeah, so basically, we received back comments from the Community Development Board on change A. They did suggest a substantive change, which is to, we had recommended that the, or we had initiated a proposal where the council would be the special permit granting authority for a number of

[Bears]: motor vehicle related uses and miscellaneous commercial uses, specifically in C1, C2 and I districts.

[Bears]: This is designed to prevent the further proliferation of motor vehicle repair shops and car yards in Mystic Ave area and other commercial areas of the city where we're looking at

[Bears]: other more significant uses than storage or repair of vehicles.

[Bears]: So I'll come back to that one, because the CD board recommendation is a significant change.

[Bears]: The second change is B, that's on page three.

[Bears]: The recodification, that language that we passed had an unintended consequence of making a lot of properties nonconforming, where you have a single parcel with multiple principal structures on the lot.

[Bears]: The CD board,

[Bears]: did suggest a language change just to specify the districts where that issue is occurring, SF1, SF2, and GR zoning, but otherwise they accepted the proposed change.

[Bears]: The third change is adding a second associate member to the Board of Appeals and clarifying term length.

[Bears]: We passed a zoning change in early 2022 that did this, but then we actually overruled it with the recodification.

[Bears]: So this is correcting us back to the language that we had passed for members appointments to the Board of Appeals and having a second associate member.

[Bears]: There were a number of unintended referrals for papers to the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: This is now the fourth one, number D.

[Bears]: of lack of clear language.

[Bears]: Basically a lot of these are we've had this new zoning recodification in place for now a little bit over a year, and the bodies that are going through it, the Zoning Board of Appeals and the Community Development Board are saying, here are some of the technical things that we think need to be updated.

[Bears]: But essentially, we're referring papers to the Community Development Board that never needed to go to them.

[Bears]: So there's a small technical change.

[Bears]: The CDB did not change.

[Bears]: Community Development Board recommendations don't change what we had proposed.

[Bears]: The fifth one is number E,

[Bears]: There was conflict between who is the special permit granting authority, and the Community Development Board recommended specific language to accomplish that objective.

[Bears]: Number six, F, the language that we passed in 2022 created an extra requirement for a special permit for inclusionary housing that's not necessary, and the Community Development Board accepted the language changes that we proposed for that.

[Bears]: G, the state agency that oversees housing changed its name this year from the Department of Housing and Community Development to the Executive Office of Housing and Livable Communities.

[Bears]: Our proposed change just updates all of those references in the zoning.

[Bears]: I think the CD board may have found one or two more.

[Bears]: They slightly changed the language, just to make it more clear, but basically the same thing.

[Bears]: And then a number of definitions were deleted from the zoning when we recodified it.

[Bears]: Several pages, I think it's pages 10 through, yeah, the whole rest of it, I think, 10 through 21, and the CD board,

[Bears]: agreed with all the ones that we included, and also found a couple other definitions that had been omitted from the recodification to include.

[Bears]: So essentially, that's the summary.

[Bears]: If we were to sever, I would recommend severing change A from changes B through G, or sorry, B through H.

[Bears]: I would like to ask that Director Hunt and Planner Evans just

[Bears]: question about the first change.

[Bears]: Change A to the use table around motor vehicle related uses.

[Bears]: It seems to me that that's the major substance of change in here from the Community Development Board recommendations, which is we had proposed that the council be

[Bears]: the Special Permit Granting Authority for a number of these uses, and the Community Development Board has recommended that they be the Special Permit Granting Authority instead, and I was just wondering if you guys could speak to the Community Development Board's reasoning or rationale behind that recommendation.

[Bears]: Is that a further question on that?

[Bears]: Thanks for that, because I didn't quite notice that, but

[Bears]: I'm guessing that's in the J, wholesale transportation, industrial uses, and then it looks like open storage under accessory uses.

[Bears]: What was the rationale between, for going to the zoning board for some of them and the city board for others?

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: Yeah, I think in general, the intent here was not to allow these kind of uses by right.

[Bears]: I like that you at the CD board came back and kind of noted some other specific uses that I think fall into a similar category as what we were looking at with the motor vehicle issue.

[Bears]: in general, I'd actually, I mean, Councilor Caraviello proposed this, so I'd like to hear from him what he thinks about it being us versus the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: Motion to approve pending the six day public comment period.

[Bears]: Madam President, motion to suspend the rules to take in the following order papers to two dash four zero one two two dash four zero two two two dash four zero three.

[Bears]: 22-395, the petition filed under public participation, 22-400, and 22-405.

[Bears]: Two, three, sorry, I wrote two, two down, I apologize.

[Bears]: All two, threes.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: There are a number of people here in the audience with us tonight, who are attending for those various papers.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: It's on page seven.

[Bears]: Could we amend the motion to also waive the readings?

[Bears]: Just waive the readings.

[Bears]: We do have Teresa, our new CPC manager.

[Bears]: I don't know if you want to say anything, Teresa.

[Bears]: You just gotta, you gotta press a little.

[Bears]: Yeah, there you go.

[Bears]: You're good.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I put this paper on.

[Bears]: There's also a paper on under public participation, which is the next item we're taking up, but maybe we could jointly have the conversation now.

[Bears]: I don't know if Elliot wants to come up in a minute,

[Bears]: Just one of the reasons I put this on is that this was something that's been a priority for me since even before I was elected.

[Bears]: Short term rentals, you know, certainly have a

[Bears]: limited place, I think, in the housing world.

[Bears]: But what we're seeing is a proliferation of a lot of our housing stock being taken up by short-term rentals and being turned into profit centers.

[Bears]: And we passed a zoning ordinance last year that put significant restrictions on short-term rentals, required registration, required them to pay a registration fee, and also limited their use, where if there is not an owner-occupant in the unit,

[Bears]: And, you know, if there's an owner occupant renting out rooms, that's one thing, but if there's just a housing unit that's being taken off the long-term rental market and being used for short-term rentals, particularly where you basically have small hotels operating in our neighborhoods, unregulated, we ban that.

[Bears]: However, Airbnb and Vrbo have not stopped listing properties that are doing that.

[Bears]: We have had residents like Mr. Jockelson and others who have been reporting, you've probably seen them on various social media sites.

[Bears]: I think there was someone who had a hot tub in a tent in their backyard that they were putting down as a short term rental.

[Bears]: And that got immediately, you know, code enforcement went out they said that's, you can't do that and it wasn't allowed but

[Bears]: the limited code enforcement resources we have in the city really mean that it's on the residents to report these situations.

[Bears]: And even when they do report them, it takes some time to get some enforcement out there.

[Bears]: I really think that we should

[Bears]: be more proactive, I think we'd find a lot of rental units coming back onto the market that are currently being used as profit centers in this way, and that would help with our housing crisis.

[Bears]: So, the two things I'm asking for are that there be more resources and requirements provided to code enforcement so that they can do their job more effectively, but also I do know that thanks to to to Mr. Jopelson and others that

[Bears]: have informed me that other cities have had created direct liaison relationships with the major short term rental sites, which have allowed the city to report issues directly to them and have listings removed so that they can't be rented.

[Bears]: So I think both of those solutions need to be explored quickly and implemented so that our zoning ordinance is being followed by these folks who are breaking the law right now.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I saw they passed something.

[Bears]: And if you're not, you can only do it a maximum of 90 days a year.

[Bears]: It's pretty strict.

[Bears]: We went pretty strict on the first pass.

[Bears]: I don't mind going and taking another look, but the most important thing is that the strict ordinance we have now be enforced.

[Bears]: And if I could just, I just do want to reiterate Councilor Knight's point, which I tried to make clear in my resolution just prior to this.

[Bears]: Two things are clear.

[Bears]: I've talked I've been working with Elliot talking to code enforcement about this I've been hearing from other folks about You know different issues code enforcement goes out when they hear about it, but they Basically the way we're doing code enforcement city generally in the way that it's structured is not what it needs to be you know essentially

[Bears]: The building departments code enforcement, and they're more focused on things like this and building inspection.

[Bears]: And yeah, and that's what I'm that's what I'm getting at.

[Bears]: Right?

[Bears]: Like they're doing great.

[Bears]: They're doing an awesome job.

[Bears]: I'm talking to them directly about what they need.

[Bears]: And you know,

[Bears]: essentially, you know, they've been doing, there should be a code enforcement officer at DPW looking at stuff in the public way.

[Bears]: The building department's been covering for that for a long time.

[Bears]: I think we need to have a serious discussion about inspectional services and code enforcement in the city.

[Bears]: What's the resource level?

[Bears]: How are they collaborating?

[Bears]: Which departments are doing each job?

[Bears]: Because clearly, on this issue, I think we're about to hear another major issue about overgrowth and trash and issues in

[Bears]: on Emory Street tonight, right?

[Bears]: Clearly they don't have the resources and the support they need.

[Bears]: The flip side of that is we can advocate, we pass the zoning ordinance, we communicate when we can, when we hear from a resident or we hear from code enforcement, we try to make those links.

[Bears]: Actually funding or making a structural change to how we do inspectional services, only the mayor has the power to do that.

[Bears]: Actually saying, hey, code enforcement,

[Bears]: You know, we need to prioritize creating an Airbnb liaison, right?

[Bears]: Only the mayor can do that.

[Bears]: So does the mayor watch this?

[Bears]: Right, and that's kind of why I'm making the statement I'm making is we've now put a resolution on, our resolutions generally get a response from the mayor.

[Bears]: The point of this resolution is to say, hey, we need to make this a priority, it's our request, please respond and tell us when and how you're going to do it.

[Bears]: Right now, all I can do is we can have another email or phone conversation with Dennis or Mike and we can- I'm gonna email the mayor next, but I'm gonna keep watching and annoying people until this house is shut down.

[Bears]: Yes, exactly.

[Bears]: And so, you know, that's what I'm saying.

[Bears]: I want to be clear that we have our eyes on it.

[Bears]: We've been working on this legislatively.

[Bears]: We're going to be pushing for it.

[Bears]: It's a partnership in a two-way street in terms of we can make the request, but the action has to come from the office of the mayor, because that's who runs enforcement and who supervises the staff of the city.

[Bears]: So- Well, now that I've spoken to you, I will now go and try and pursue it there.

[Bears]: Yeah, and I'm happy to help on that direction too.

[Bears]: I would love to have a conversation with the council and the mayor and code enforcement about what should inspectional services look like.

[Bears]: in the city as well.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I just want to add, I think on this specific one, you found the answer, which is we should just be saying directly to the company, you have to remove the listing.

[Bears]: And that, that, that strips out the entire process.

[Bears]: And then, you know, you have the people with the authority to make that from the city side who have the legal authority to have that enforcement happen.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: I believe it's one large six-story building and then smaller outbuilding.

[Bears]: Oh, can I go first?

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I wanna acknowledge what Mr. Paige Lieberman just said.

[Bears]: I think it's not targeting people who use Airbnb.

[Bears]: I think there's obviously cases and situations where there's need for people to have short-term accommodations.

[Bears]: I think it's the question of, historically, until these app companies came in and said, oh, we're gonna make a premium off of people's homes, renting them out,

[Bears]: people stayed at hotels, which have regulations, they have specific security requirements, taxation requirements, there is a suites, I think it's a town place suites or some Marriott suites in Medford that has a kitchen and some bedrooms in it, right?

[Bears]: Like, but while there are certainly reasonable and valid use cases, I think when you have a

[Bears]: there are people renting single family homes for $1,000 a night.

[Bears]: If you can make $360,000 a year, and maybe you won't rent it out every night, but say you rent it out half the nights, you can make $180,000 a year, why would you ever rent it long-term to a long-term tenant?

[Bears]: You just wouldn't.

[Bears]: I mean, I wouldn't do that, but if you're just buying property to speculate on and seek profit motive, if you can make $180,000 a year versus $40,000 a year,

[Bears]: you know, someone who has that profit motive or chooses to speculate on the land and housing in our community.

[Bears]: since we don't regulate it, they're gonna do that.

[Bears]: And I just think that's, it's not about targeting the people who use Airbnbs, it's targeting the people who are buying housing and land in the city and turning it into micro hotels in neighborhoods that are unregulated because they can make an extra $100,000 a year off of land that should be used for people to live here, to live here.

[Bears]: And that's really more where I'm coming from on it.

[Bears]: I'm not one to,

[Bears]: Be mad that people are having fun.

[Bears]: I like having fun too.

[Bears]: So I just don't think that the landlord making $100,000 a year in profit by taking a housing unit away from a family who wants to live here should be able to do so.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: We've done a lot of good legislating we passed the road and control ordinance we passed the zoning ordinance on short term rental, we've tried to pass things giving code enforcement clear authority we've passed are working closely to pass a new waste ordinance right.

[Bears]: And we passed all these ordinances, and the staffing isn't there or the, you know, for whatever reason.

[Bears]: the administration doesn't enforce those ordinances to the letter, and that is where the difficulty comes in, is we can pass the strongest and as many ordinances as we want, but if they don't get enforced by the mayor and her team, or the mayor doesn't come to us and say, I need more resources to enforce this ordinance, then we end up where we are, which is passing good ordinances that then don't get the follow-through that they need.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: even using what we have to the best of its effectiveness.

[Bears]: The Tufts RAs went on a one-day strike last week, and I was happy to support them and this council also.

[Bears]: asked Tufts to recognize their union and instead Tufts forced an election, which lengthened the process by months.

[Bears]: And now we have the contract process lengthened by months.

[Bears]: So these folks don't have a fair contract when the new school year started.

[Bears]: And really the most important thing about that is

[Bears]: whether it's RAs or students on campus or residents in the neighborhood around Tufts who are not getting fair and equitable treatment by Tufts or Tufts is taking actions that negatively impact the community or the folks on campus, we're all in the same fight.

[Bears]: Tufts is a billion dollar institution, multi-billion dollar institution run by a small group of people who make decisions that a lot of people disagree with.

[Bears]: And we can all fight our fights with Tufts separately if we want, but we're actually stronger together.

[Bears]: So one of the reasons I think it's important for community members and the city council to support the Tufts RAs is because if we build that relationship, we can call on the Tufts RAs to support us in asking for and fighting for a bigger pilot.

[Bears]: And there was an interview today, the Tufts Daily interviewed the new president of Tufts, and

[Bears]: the student reporters were making that point too.

[Bears]: They said, well, what about the impact that Tufts has on the surrounding community?

[Bears]: And the president says, oh, we, you know, new president says that we try really hard.

[Bears]: But he said, you know, we wanted to hear about this.

[Bears]: We want to try really hard to support this.

[Bears]: And the student pushed back.

[Bears]: So we have the narrative that we've been talking about by reaching out to Tufts students, reaching out and working with the workers on campus about the impact of Tufts on the communities and the neighborhoods that it lives in.

[Bears]: That message is breaking through.

[Bears]: And if we can all work together to hold Tufts accountable to do better, we have a much better shot than we do of doing it alone.

[Bears]: So that is the larger message and point of why it's important to build relationships and show solidarity like this, because what goes around comes around.

[Bears]: They're mistreating the RAs today.

[Bears]: that we mistreat in the neighborhood tomorrow and someone else the next day, and it's better off if we work together to fight that than if we do it alone.

[Bears]: Sure.

[Bears]: I don't care if it's illegal or not illegal by state law.

[Bears]: It's a bad law.

[Bears]: And it means that bargaining goes on forever for 700, 800, 900 days with no timeline on it.

[Bears]: And the workers have no leverage, right?

[Bears]: The point of the union is that you have collective power and part of collective power is taking a job action.

[Bears]: I guarantee you if the firefighters in the community, which is an even bigger thing to go public safety, right?

[Bears]: The firefighters in the community went on strike for 12 hours.

[Bears]: Everyone in the city would lose their minds and they'd have a contract the next day.

[Bears]: I'm not saying that's the best policy in the world, but at the very least state law needs to change so that they don't sit for 700 days before a contract goes to arbitration.

[Bears]: You know, we support the workers to, there's a lot that needs to change around public sector bargaining.

[Bears]: This would create a trust of the provisions of state law where

[Bears]: City funds private funds etc could be pulled for the benefit of creating more affordable housing in the community.

[Bears]: This has been reported out of committee, just the latest updates.

[Bears]: Number four should be replaced with the remaining members.

[Bears]: It says the board shall be composed of seven members, but then it says one shall be the mayor.

[Bears]: One may be a member of the Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: And then it says four, that would only add up to six or maybe even five if the may of the Community Preservation Committee members considered.

[Bears]: So I just proposed a technical amendment to strike the number four and replace it with the words, the remaining members.

[Bears]: And then in section 49-54, subsection 11, just clarifying language here.

[Bears]: that we had put into the ordinance, just to explain that borrowed by the trust shall pledge any borrowing that pledges more than 70% of the cash assets of the trust for Park City Council approvals.

[Bears]: It was just a little bit confusing there.

[Bears]: And I talked that over with planning development and sustainability.

[Bears]: So I would move to amend

[Bears]: the ordinance to reflect those two technical amendments, which all Councilors should have and the clerk should have.

[Bears]: And I would also move to attach the letter of comment received from the Greater Boston Labor Council and require the trustees to incorporate the language provided by the Greater Boston Labor Council into the rules and regulations of the Affordable Housing Trust.

[Bears]: And so that would be the language that we received back regarding project labor agreements.

[Bears]: It clearly reads any borrowing by the trust that pledges, any borrowing by the trust pledging more than 75, 70% of the assets of the trust requires city council approval.

[Bears]: The change would be any borrowing by the trust that pledges more than 70% of the cash assets of the trust requires city council approval.

[Bears]: And I would propose those amendments and to approve the ordinance for first reading.

[Bears]: And then in two weeks, we will have some sort of response back from the Attorney General.

[Bears]: It may not be a full response.

[Bears]: It may say, this is the process you need to go through to get us to do this, or we don't do this, or whatever else it may be.

[Bears]: But I just wanted to put some timelines and a shock box on the whole thing, because I agree we need the right answer, but I also agree that we should try to move as fast as we can.

[Bears]: Does that make sense to everybody, the three folks who proposed motions?

[Bears]: Any members of the Council wish to speak, I'm happy to hear from them first.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I respect my colleagues positions on this.

[Bears]: I think

[Bears]: There's been a number of issues.

[Bears]: I think that maybe the chain of events and the opinions are getting a little bit conflated, but I, again, I respect my fellow councilors positions.

[Bears]: To me, the way that this is presented tonight, it's very clear that a new position in the city does not exist until it is approved in the cap.

[Bears]: This is presented as a new position to be added to the cap, which did not exist prior to any action that we take on this.

[Bears]: We did receive legal advice from KP Law, a memorandum from KP Law around these issues, clearly delineating the requirements of Chapter 44, Section 33A.

[Bears]: And when it comes to creating a new position,

[Bears]: that requires four votes.

[Bears]: If it's something else, there's other requirements.

[Bears]: But this is, I think, to me, very similar to the senior planner position that was created by this council and amended to the CAF in late last year.

[Bears]: And I also think, and I'm just gonna say what I said at that meeting,

[Bears]: The work that we do here is a balancing of interests and a balancing of what's best for the city.

[Bears]: I personally feel confident on this paper and the legal justification behind it.

[Bears]: And I also feel that.

[Bears]: this person that the creation of a traffic and transportation director, and making sure that a person who fills that role has the multiple years of experience with the city that the person who would, you know, likely be taking the role has is essential, and we know that there are

[Bears]: not enough experts to fill too many open jobs.

[Bears]: There are other communities, there are state agencies that are looking for people with the expertise of this position and that's why I personally am going to support this tonight because I want to make sure that this city

[Bears]: that we as a city council are making sure that the city has the staff and tools that the city needs to be successful.

[Bears]: And that's my reasoning.

[Bears]: So thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Yeah, and the other thing I would just say is I do believe the traffic and transportation director and the position was included in the new unit of management positions that was organized by level 25.

[Bears]: So I don't believe there'll be a loss of the union position.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Collins for sponsoring this.

[Bears]: I believe, I can't remember which one of us did it last time, but it was me.

[Bears]: You know, I think you made really great points.

[Bears]: Something that we did two years ago is we were able to look at assessor data at the City of Medford.

[Bears]: And if Tufts, just Tufts for example, was taxed at the same rate as

[Bears]: was taxed at all for property taxes.

[Bears]: They would pay $8 million a year in property taxes.

[Bears]: Now, this law would only require up to 25% of what they would nominally pay, so it would be about $2 million a year.

[Bears]: But I just want to say since we've had the discussions here tonight.

[Bears]: That's $2 million for sidewalk crew to support our firefighters to support all the emergency calls that go out to tops to support street and sidewalk infrastructure repairs in their area to support affordable housing in the area around the top neighborhood, and I'm just putting that out there to say.

[Bears]: I can understand why a nonprofit education or healthcare institution maybe shouldn't be treated the same as a for profit business, but I don't think the answer is that they should be treated, it should be 100% for one and 0% for the other.

[Bears]: And I also want to put out there to this isn't just about tops.

[Bears]: This is about all of the large nonprofit institutions, and whether or not they play pay pilot payments to the city tops for example while this legislation would allow basically up to $2 million.

[Bears]: If they paid normal private tax to be $8 million tops right now pays $450,000 to the city.

[Bears]: But other pilot agreements such as right across the street from this building, Harvard Vanguard used to pay a trace health whatever it is now.

[Bears]: They used to pay a pilot agreement and they pulled out of their power agreement unilaterally without any city engagement they no longer provide any.

[Bears]: pilot payment to the city.

[Bears]: Something I'm exploring actually is that Atrius Health was just bought up and is now a for-profit institution, so maybe they'll have to start paying.

[Bears]: But my point is to say that right now, the way that the current state law reads,

[Bears]: it's up to the discretion of the institution.

[Bears]: And that means that even if you have an agreement, the institution could pull out at any time and leave the city holding the bag.

[Bears]: And we're already holding the bag for all the services and needs in the areas around these large institutions that they're not paying their fair share for.

[Bears]: So I really hope

[Bears]: that the State House can do something to create a fair system where we're still understanding that these are nonprofit health and education institutions that should have some benefit, but that benefit shouldn't be all or nothing the way it is now.

[Bears]: And furthermore, just to drive home the point, this is for large property owners, the threshold, your property has to be worth, I believe, over $15 million to even be qualified under this suggested amendment.

[Bears]: So thank you, Councilor Collins, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you to my fellow councilors, Councilor Caraviello.

[Bears]: Those numbers could have changed the results of an election.

[Bears]: almost 130 ballots in one precinct that somehow didn't get counted in the unofficial count, right?

[Bears]: And that's incredibly important to the community that

[Bears]: We have answers to those questions and answers to the process and fixes to the process and staffing and resources in that department.

[Bears]: So that we have confidence that, number one, mistakes that were made in the past aren't going to be made again.

[Bears]: And number two, when mistakes happen, which in any human endeavor is inevitable that there will be things that go wrong.

[Bears]: the public is made aware and the candidates are made aware right away.

[Bears]: I think that's really the most important thing.

[Bears]: I know in the past when issues did occur, you know, and I haven't been involved as long as some other folks here, but Sandy Gale, Clark Hurtubise, others really did try to get the word out right away.

[Bears]: We had this issue.

[Bears]: We want you to know what the issue was.

[Bears]: We want you to know

[Bears]: how we tried to address it, or who we brought in to help address it.

[Bears]: I know that Finn had done similar things as well.

[Bears]: And that has to be how our elections offices operate, right?

[Bears]: If there is an issue, you get the word out right away.

[Bears]: The operating procedure can't be that if there's an issue, you try to fix it without anyone noticing, because that just does not bring trust.

[Bears]: So

[Bears]: putting this on, formally putting on an item for this report to be on our agenda with the deadline of January 23rd, which is our first regular meeting after the next election commission meeting.

[Bears]: I just think it might be helpful, I know this is kind of more for specific questions, but if possible, if Attorneys Everett and or Stein could give a

[Bears]: general framework of what state law is around private ways and how that impacts the city.

[Bears]: I think that would be a good starting point just to understand maybe what we can do, what we can't do, and then what is more within our discretion as a city by policy or ordinance.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I had two questions.

[Bears]: One was along those lines.

[Bears]: So it sounds like we're going to have a website where people can go, if I live on a private way, here's the law.

[Bears]: This is what the city does.

[Bears]: This is what the city doesn't do.

[Bears]: Those are the expectations I should have for service provision on a private way.

[Bears]: I think that'd be great.

[Bears]: I know police have had some engineering.

[Bears]: We've had a few.
